Get Latest Financial Information and Ticker Symbol From Company Name(s)

Source: R/search_fn.R
search_summary.Rd

Get latest overall insights and ticker symbols associated with free texts, such as companies texts. Several ticker symbols associated with various exchanges places could be returned, with , companies texts, last price on the marketplace, sector/category (if available), etc.

Usage

search_summary(texts, exchange = NULL, sector = NULL)

Arguments

texts

A character string representing the company name to search for.

exchange

(optionnal) A character string representing the exchange place(s) to consider (exact match). Default keep all the exchange places.

sector

(optionnal) A character string representing the sector(s) to consider (exact match). Default keep all results.

Value

A data frame with columns:

symbol

character - The ticker symbol associated with an asset, e.g., "VTI", "^DWCPF".

name

character - Name of the asset, e.g., ETF or index name.

last_price

numeric - The last price of the asset.

sector

character - The sector or industry category if available, e.g., 'Industrials', 'Consumer Cyclical'.

type

character - The type of asset (certainly "stocks").

exchange

character - The stock exchange place for this asset, e.g., 'PAR' is Paris (FR) exchange place.

searched

character - The text searched on Yahoo, e.g., "Dow Jones".

Details

Return a data.frame with additionnal attributes:

n.currencies

integer - Number of unique currencies in the data.frame.

currencies

character - A vector of currency symbols in the data.frame (e.g., "BTC", "ETH", "USD").

exchange

character - A vector of exchange pairs (e.g., "BTC => USD"). If not applicable, NULL (no entry).

date

Date - The date when the data was retrieved, set using Sys.Date().

crypto

logical - TRUE if cryptocurrencies are present, otherwise FALSE.

References

Source : search on https://finance.yahoo.com/lookup/

See also

For more details see the help vignette: vignette("get_info_and_historic", package = "financr")

Examples

oil <- search_summary(texts = c("Dow Jones", "Euronext"))
#Get data on marketplace(s)
cars <- search_summary(texts = c("RENAULT", "VOLVO"),  exchange = c("STO", "PAR"))
